fr:title.text: The internalization of a small fibration

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: The internalization of a small fibration

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let E be a small fibration over B a category with finite limits, i.e. a cartesian fibration that is both locally small and globally small. We will show that E is equivalent to the externalization {\mathopen {}\left [C\right ]\mathclose {}} of an internal category C in B, namely the full internal subcategory associated to the generic object \bar {u}\in E.

By the characterization of the externalization we know that the externalization of C so-defined is equivalent to the full subfibration \mathbf {Full}{\mathopen {}\left (\bar {u}\right )\mathclose {}} of E spanned by objects that are “classified” by \bar {u}. Because \bar {u} is generic, we know that every object of E is classified by \bar {u}, so we are done.
Cocartesian fibrations are a dual notion to cartesian fibrations, in which the variance of indexing is reversed.

Let E be displayed over B, and let f:x\to y \in B; a morphism \bar {f}:\bar {x}\xrightarrow [f]{} \bar {y} in E is called cocartesian over f when for any m:y\to u and \bar {h}:\bar {x}\xrightarrow [f;m]{} \bar {u} there exists a unique \bar {m} : \bar {y}\xrightarrow [m]{} \bar {u} with \bar {f};\bar {m} = \bar {h}:
We use a “pushout corner” to indicate \bar {x}\to \bar {y} as a cocartesian morphism, a notation justified by our discussion of the dual self-indexing.

A displayed category E over B is a cocartesian fibration when for each f : x \to y\in B and \bar {x}\in E_{x}, there exists a displayed object \bar {y}\in E_{y} and a cocartesian morphism \bar {f} : \bar {x}\xrightarrow [f]{} \bar {y}.
Cocartesian fibrations are also known as opfibrations.

fr:title.text: The total opposite of a displayed category

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: The total opposite of a displayed category

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let E be displayed over B; we define its total opposite E^{\tilde {\mathsf {o}}} displayed over B^{\mathsf {op}} as follows:

html:ol.html:li: An object of E^{\tilde {\mathsf {o}}}_{x} is given by an object of E_{x}.
Given f : x \to y\in B^{\mathsf {op}}, a displayed morphism \bar {x}\xrightarrow [f]{} \bar {y} in E^{\tilde {\mathsf {o}}} is given by a displayed morphism \bar {y}\xrightarrow [f]{} \bar {x} in E.

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Warning. Do not confuse this construction with the opposite fibered category, which produces a displayed category over B and not B^{\mathsf {op}}.

Let E be displayed over B. Prove that the total category \widetilde {E^{\tilde {\mathsf {o}}}} is {\mathopen {}\left (\widetilde {E}\right )\mathclose {}}^{\mathsf {op}}, and its projection functor is {\mathopen {}\left (p_{E}\right )\mathclose {}}^{\mathsf {op}} : \widetilde {E}^{\mathsf {op}}\to B^{\mathsf {op}}.

Let E be displayed over B, and let f:x\to y\in B. Prove that a morphism \bar {f}:\bar {x}\xrightarrow [f]{}\bar {y} is cartesian over f in E if and only if \bar {f}:\bar {y}\xrightarrow [f]{}\bar {x} is cocartesian over f in E^{\tilde {\mathsf {o}}}.
Prove that a displayed category E is a cartesian fibration over B if and only if E^{\tilde {\mathsf {o}}} is a cocartesian fibration over B^{\mathsf {op}}.

Recall that the fundamental self-indexing \underline {B} of a category B is a displayed category with \underline {B}_{x} = {B}_{/x}. Recall that \underline {B} is a cartesian fibration over B if and only if B has pullbacks. However, \underline {B} is unconditionally a cocartesian fibration.
Prove that the fundamental self-indexing \underline {B} is a cocartesian fibration for any category B.
Dually to the fundamental self-indexing, every category B can also be displayed over itself via its coslices B^{\setminus x}.
Let B be a category. Define the displayed category \overline {B} over B as follows:

html:ol.html:li: For x\in B, define \overline {B}_{x} as the collection of pairs (\bar {x}\in B,p_{x}:x\to \bar {x}).
For f : x\to y\in B, define \overline {B}_{f} to be the collection of commuting squares in the following configuration:

fr:resource.fr:resource-source: \DiagramSquare { height = 1.7cm, sw = \bar {x}, se = \bar {y}, nw = x, ne = y, west = p_{x}, east = p_{y}, south = \bar {f}, north = f, west/style = {->,exists}, east/style = {->,exists}, south/style = {->,exists}, }

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Prove that \overline {B} is a cocartesian fibration if and only if B has pushouts.
Prove that the total category of \overline {B} is the arrow category B^{\to }, and the projection is the domain functor.
Prove that \overline {B} is a cartesian fibration for any category B.
A cartesian fibration E over B is said to be a right fibration when all displayed morphisms in E are cartesian.
Recall that for every b\in B, the collection of displayed objects E_{b} and vertical maps E_{1_{b}} forms a category. When E is a right fibration over B, this category is in fact a groupoid.
A cartesian fibration E over B is a right fibration if and only if all its vertical maps are isomorphisms.

Suppose that E is a right fibration over B, and fix b\in B, \bar {b}\in E_{b}, and a vertical map f:\bar {b}\xrightarrow [1_{b}]{} \bar {b}. Using the hypothesis that f is cartesian, it has a unique section g:\bar {b}\xrightarrow [1_{b}]{} \bar {b} as follows:
Likewise, because g is cartesian, f is the unique section of g; thus f is an isomorphism in E_{b}.

Conversely, suppose that E is a cartesian fibration whose vertical maps are isomorphisms. Fix f:x\to y \in B and an arbitrary displayed morphism \bar {g}:\bar {x}\xrightarrow [f]{}\bar {y}. Then \bar {g} is the precomposition of a cartesian lift \bar {f}:\bar {x}'\xrightarrow [f]{}\bar {y} with a vertical map:

Because vertical maps are isomorphisms and \bar {f} is cartesian, we can observe that \bar {g} is cartesian as follows, writing \bar {m} : \bar {u}\xrightarrow [m]{} \bar {x}' for the unique factorization of \bar {h} through \bar {f} over m:
These are the trees that I am thinking about right now.
A directed graph G is defined to be a collection of 0-cells A,B,C,\ldots \in G together with a collection of edges {A}\xrightarrow {{e}}{B}\in G.

fr:title.text: Free category on a directed graph

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Free category on a directed graph

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let G be a directed graph; a path in G is defined to be a sequence of compatible edges {\mathopen {}\left [A_0\xrightarrow {f_0}A_1\xrightarrow {f_1}\ldots \xrightarrow {f_{n-1}}A_n\right ]\mathclose {}}. Evidently, the free category G^{\star } on G has morphisms given by paths.
A virtual bicategory \mathcal {K} is a directed graph equipped with the following additional data:

html:ol.html:li: for each path {A}\xrightarrow {{\Psi }}{B}\in \mathcal {K}^{\star } and each edge {A}\xrightarrow {{f}}{B}\in \mathcal {K}, a collection of 2-cells {\Psi }\xrightarrow {{\alpha }}{f}\in \mathcal {K}{\mathopen {}\left (A,B\right )\mathclose {}};
for any edge {A}\xrightarrow {{f}}{B}, an identity 2-cell {{\mathopen {}\left [f\right ]\mathclose {}}}\xrightarrow {{1_{f}}}{f}\in \mathcal {K}{\mathopen {}\left (A,B\right )\mathclose {}};

for any sequence of compatible paths A_0\xrightarrow {\Psi _0}\ldots \xrightarrow {\Psi _{n-1}}A_n\in \mathcal {K}^{\star } and 2-cells {\Psi _i}\xrightarrow {{\alpha _i}}{f_i}\in \mathcal {K}{\mathopen {}\left (A_i,A_{i+1}\right )\mathclose {}} and {{\mathopen {}\left [f_i\mid i<n\right ]\mathclose {}}}\xrightarrow {{\beta }}{g}\in \mathcal {K}{\mathopen {}\left (A_0,A_n\right )\mathclose {}}, a composite 2-cell {\Psi _0;\ldots ;\Psi _n}\xrightarrow {{{\mathopen {}\left [\alpha _i\mid i<n\right ]\mathclose {}};\beta }}{g};
such that the composition of 2-cells is both associative and unital with respect to identity 2-cells.

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let \mathcal {K} be a virtual bicategory; given a path {A}\xrightarrow {{\Psi }}{B}\in \mathcal {K}^{\star } and an edge {A}\xrightarrow {{f}}{B}, a 2-cell {\Psi }\xrightarrow {{\alpha }}{f} is called cocartesian if any 2-cell {\Phi ;\Psi ;\Xi }\xrightarrow {{\beta }}{s} factors uniquely through \alpha in the sense that there exists a unique 2-cell {\Phi ;{\mathopen {}\left [f\right ]\mathclose {}};\Xi }\xrightarrow {{\beta \setminus \alpha }}{s} such that \beta = {\mathopen {}\left [\overrightarrow {1_{\Phi _i}\ldots },\alpha ,\overrightarrow {1_{\Xi _i}\ldots }\right ]\mathclose {}};{\mathopen {}\left (\beta \setminus \alpha \right )\mathclose {}}.

fr:title.text: Left- and right-cocartesian 2-cells in a virtual bicategory

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Left- and right-cocartesian 2-cells in a virtual bicategory

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let \mathcal {K} be a virtual bicategory; given a path {A}\xrightarrow {{\Psi }}{B}\in \mathcal {K}^{\star } and an edge {A}\xrightarrow {{f}}{B}, a 2-cell {\Psi }\xrightarrow {{\alpha }}{f} is called left-cocartesian if for 2-cell {\Psi ;\Xi }\xrightarrow {{\beta }}{s} factors uniquely through \alpha in the sense that there exists a unique 2-cell {{\mathopen {}\left [f\right ]\mathclose {}};\Psi }\xrightarrow {{\beta \setminus \alpha }}{s} such that \beta = {\mathopen {}\left [\alpha ,\overrightarrow {1_{\Xi _i}\ldots }\right ]\mathclose {}};{\mathopen {}\left (\beta \setminus \alpha \right )\mathclose {}}.

Dually, given a path {B}\xrightarrow {{\Psi }}{C}\in \mathcal {K}^{\star } and an edge {B}\xrightarrow {{f}}{C}, a 2-cell {\Psi }\xrightarrow {{\alpha }}{f} is called right-cocartesian if for 2-cell {\Phi ;\Psi }\xrightarrow {{\beta }}{s} factors uniquely through \alpha in the sense that there exists a unique 2-cell {\Phi ;{\mathopen {}\left [f\right ]\mathclose {}}}\xrightarrow {{\beta \setminus \alpha }}{s} such that \beta = {\mathopen {}\left [\overrightarrow {1_{\Phi _i}\ldots },\alpha \right ]\mathclose {}};{\mathopen {}\left (\beta \setminus \alpha \right )\mathclose {}}.
These definitions are due to Arkor and McDermott.
Let \mathcal {K} be a virtual bicategory, and let {A}\xrightarrow {{\Psi }}{B}\in \mathcal {K}^{\star } be a path in \mathcal {K}. Then we define:

html:ol.html:li: a composite of \Psi is a cocartesian 2-cell with domain \Psi ;
a left half-composite of \Psi is a left-cocartesian 2-cell with domain \Psi ;
a right half-composite of \Psi is a right-cocartesian 2-cell with domain \Psi .

fr:title.text: Bicategories are virtual bicategories with all composites

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Bicategories are virtual bicategories with all composites

fr:mainmatter.html:p: A bicategory is the same thing as a virtual bicategory that has all composites, as observed by Derek Elkins.

I still don't know if the following are the correct definitions. One would have to check that the left-composite of a pair of maps is isomorphic to the right-composite if both exist, which sounds plausible.

fr:title.text: Thunkable and linear maps in a virtual bicategory

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Thunkable and linear maps in a virtual bicategory

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let \mathcal {K} be a virtual bicategory; we isolate two classes of edges:

html:ol.html:li: an edge {A}\xrightarrow {{f}}{B} in \mathcal {K} is called thunkable if and only if for any edge {B}\xrightarrow {{g}}{C} there exists a left half-composite {{\mathopen {}\left [f;g\right ]\mathclose {}}}\xrightarrow {{\lambda }}{h};

dually, an edge {B}\xrightarrow {{g}}{C} in \mathcal {K} is called linear if and only if for any edge {A}\xrightarrow {{f}}{B} there exists a right half-composite {{\mathopen {}\left [f;g\right ]\mathclose {}}}\xrightarrow {{\rho }}{h}.

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let \mathcal {K} be a virtual bicategory; we isolate two classes of objects in \mathcal {K}, by analogy with the case for deductive systems:

html:ol.html:li: an object B\in \mathcal {K} is called positive when every edge {B}\xrightarrow {{f}}{C} is linear;
an object B\in \mathcal {K} is called negative when every edge {A}\xrightarrow {{f}}{B} is thunkable.

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Then we say that an object is polarized when it is either positive or negative in the above sense.

I am accumulating an understanding of constructive domain theory — that is, the domain theory that can be carried out in an elementary topos with a natural numbers object. These notes are based on the work of Tom de Jong and Martín Escardó; these notes, however, assume the propositional resizing principle whereas de Jong and Escardó explore a predicative version domain theory based on large and locally small domains.

In this section, we gather some useful definitions and results concerning creation of (co)limits. The reason for stating these things explicitly is that the usual definitions of created (co)limits are deeply irrational in a variety of incompatible ways, so it is important to fix definitions that can work from the start. It would be good to reformulate this in terms of displayed categories of algebras.

Let {\mathcal {C}}\xrightarrow {{U}}{\mathcal {D}} be a functor and let \mathcal {I} be a category. The functor U is said to create (co)limits of \mathcal {I}-figures when for any diagram {\mathcal {I}}\xrightarrow {{C_\bullet }}{\mathcal {C}} such that \mathcal {I}\xrightarrow {C_\bullet }\mathcal {C}\xrightarrow {U}\mathcal {D} has a (co)limit, then C_\bullet has a (co)limit that is both preserved and reflected by U.
We aim to understand sufficient conditions for a forgetful functor to create colimits. As we will show below, it is sufficient for these colimits to be preserved the the monad.

fr:title.text: Algebra structure on the colimit apex

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Algebra structure on the colimit apex

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let \mathcal {C} be a category and let \mathbb {T} = {\mathopen {}\left (T,\eta ,\mu \right )\mathclose {}} be a monad on \mathcal {C}, writing {\mathcal {C}^{\mathbb {T}}}\xrightarrow {{U}}{\mathcal {C}} for the forgetful functor from the Eilenberg–Moore category \mathcal {C}^{\mathbb {T}}. Suppose that T preserves colimits of \mathcal {I}-figures for a given small category \mathcal {I}. Let {\mathcal {I}}\xrightarrow {{X_\bullet }}{\mathcal {C}^{\mathbb {T}}} be a diagram in \mathcal {C}^{\mathbb {T}} such that \mathcal {I}\xrightarrow {X_\bullet }\mathcal {C}^{\mathbb {T}}\xrightarrow {U}\mathcal {C} has a universal cocone {UX_\bullet }\xrightarrow {{c_\bullet }}{{\mathopen {}\left \{C\right \}\mathclose {}}}. We may lift C to an essentially unique \mathbb {T}-algebra structure \bar {C} with U\bar {C}=C in a canonical way such that {UX_\bullet }\xrightarrow {{c_\bullet }}{{\mathopen {}\left \{C\right \}\mathclose {}}} lifts to a cocone of algebras {X_{\bullet }}\xrightarrow {{\bar {c}_{\bullet }}}{\bar {C}} with U\bar {c}_\bullet =c_\bullet .

By assumption, {TUX_\bullet }\xrightarrow {{Tc_\bullet }}{{\mathopen {}\left \{TC\right \}\mathclose {}}} is a universal cocone. We may define a further cocone TUX_\bullet \xrightarrow {\alpha _{X_\bullet }}UX_\bullet \xrightarrow {c_\bullet }{\mathopen {}\left \{C\right \}\mathclose {}}. The universal property of Tc_\bullet then gives us a unique morphism {TC}\xrightarrow {{\beta }}{C} satisfying the following condition:

fr:resource.fr:resource-source: \DiagramSquare { nw = TUX_\bullet , sw = UX_\bullet , ne = {\mathopen {}\left \{TC\right \}\mathclose {}}, se = {\mathopen {}\left \{C\right \}\mathclose {}}, west = \alpha _{X_\bullet }, south = c_\bullet , east = \exists !{\mathopen {}\left \{\beta \right \}\mathclose {}}, north = Tc_\bullet , east/style = {exists,->}, }

fr:mainmatter.html:p: We must show that the map {TC}\xrightarrow {{\beta }}{C} depicted above satisfies the axioms of a \mathbb {T}-algebra.

html:li.html:p: To show that C\xrightarrow {\eta _C}TC\xrightarrow {\beta }C is the identity, we note that {UX_\bullet }\xrightarrow {{c_\bullet }}{{\mathopen {}\left \{C\right \}\mathclose {}}} is universal so it suffices to check that UX_\bullet \xrightarrow {c_\bullet }{\mathopen {}\left \{C\right \}\mathclose {}}\xrightarrow {{\mathopen {}\left \{\eta _C\right \}\mathclose {}}}{\mathopen {}\left \{TC\right \}\mathclose {}}\xrightarrow {{\mathopen {}\left \{\beta \right \}\mathclose {}}}{{\mathopen {}\left \{C\right \}\mathclose {}}} is equal to c_\bullet by the uniqueness property. This follows by inspection of the following commuting diagram, in which the top square is the naturality of the unit:
We must check that the the following multiplication square commutes:

fr:resource.fr:resource-source: \DiagramSquare { nw = TTC, ne = TC, sw = TC, se = C, east = \beta , south = \beta , north = T\beta , west = \mu _C, }

html:li.html:p: By assumption, we know that {TTUX_\bullet }\xrightarrow {{TTc_\bullet }}{{\mathopen {}\left \{TTC\right \}\mathclose {}}} is a universal cocone; using this fact as well as the naturality of \mu , it suffices to check that the following diagram commutes:

fr:resource.fr:resource-source: \begin {tikzpicture}[diagram] \SpliceDiagramSquare <l/>{ east/style = {draw=none}, nw = TTUX_\bullet , sw = TUX_\bullet , ne = {\mathopen {}\left \{TTC\right \}\mathclose {}}, se = {\mathopen {}\left \{TC\right \}\mathclose {}}, north = TTc_\bullet , south = Tc_\bullet , west = \mu _{UX_\bullet }, width = 2.5cm, } \SpliceDiagramSquare <r/>{ glue target = l/, glue = west, ne = {\mathopen {}\left \{TC\right \}\mathclose {}}, se = {\mathopen {}\left \{C\right \}\mathclose {}}, north = {\mathopen {}\left \{T\beta \right \}\mathclose {}}, east = {\mathopen {}\left \{\beta \right \}\mathclose {}}, south = {\mathopen {}\left \{\beta \right \}\mathclose {}}, width = 2.5cm, } \end {tikzpicture}

html:li.html:p: We compute algebraically, using the algebra property of X among other assumptions:

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Hence we may define a \mathbb {T}-algebra structure \bar {C} with U\bar {C}=C, setting {TC}\xrightarrow {{\alpha _{\bar {C}}}}{C} to be \beta . That c_\bullet lifts to a cocone of algebras is exactly the defining condition of \alpha _{\bar {C}}=\beta via the universal property of {TUX_\bullet }\xrightarrow {{Tc_\bullet }}{{\mathopen {}\left \{TC\right \}\mathclose {}}}; uniqueness of the algebra structure with this property follows from the same universal property.

fr:title.text: Reflection of colimits by the forgetful functor

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Reflection of colimits by the forgetful functor

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let \mathcal {C} be a category and let \mathbb {T} = {\mathopen {}\left (T,\eta ,\mu \right )\mathclose {}} be a monad on \mathcal {C}, writing {\mathcal {C}^{\mathbb {T}}}\xrightarrow {{U}}{\mathcal {C}} for the forgetful functor from the Eilenberg–Moore category \mathcal {C}^{\mathbb {T}}. If T preserves colimits of \mathcal {I}-figures for a given indexing category \mathcal {I}, then {\mathcal {C}^{\mathbb {T}}}\xrightarrow {{U}}{\mathcal {C}} reflects colimits of \mathcal {I}-figures.

Let {\mathcal {I}}\xrightarrow {{X_\bullet }}{\mathcal {C}^{\mathbb {T}}} be a diagram in \mathcal {C}^{\mathbb {T}} and let {X_\bullet }\xrightarrow {{y_\bullet }}{{\mathopen {}\left \{Y\right \}\mathclose {}}} be a cocone in \mathcal {C}^{\mathbb {T}} such that {UX_\bullet }\xrightarrow {{Uy_\bullet }}{{\mathopen {}\left \{UY\right \}\mathclose {}}} is a universal cocone for UX_\bullet = \mathcal {I}\xrightarrow {X_\bullet }\mathcal {C}^{\mathbb {T}}\xrightarrow {U}\mathcal {C}. We must show that {X_\bullet }\xrightarrow {{y_\bullet }}{{\mathopen {}\left \{Y\right \}\mathclose {}}} is a universal cocone.

In particular, we must factor any cocone {X_\bullet }\xrightarrow {{z_\bullet }}{{\mathopen {}\left \{Z\right \}\mathclose {}}} uniquely through {X_\bullet }\xrightarrow {{y_\bullet }}{{\mathopen {}\left \{Y\right \}\mathclose {}}}. Because Uy_\bullet is universal, there exists a unique {Y}\xrightarrow {{h}}{Z} such that the following diagram commutes:
We must check that h is a homomorphism of \mathbb {T}-algebras:

fr:resource.fr:resource-source: \DiagramSquare { nw = TUY, sw = TUZ, ne = UY, se = UZ, south = \alpha _Z, north = \alpha _Y, west = Th, east = h, }

fr:mainmatter.html:p: To see that \alpha _Y;h = Th;\alpha _Z it suffices to observe that they both factor the cocone
through the cocone {TUX_\bullet }\xrightarrow {{TUy_\bullet }}{{\mathopen {}\left \{TUY\right \}\mathclose {}}}, which is universal by our assumption that T preserves \mathcal {I}-colimits.

html:li.html:p: First we must check that the following diagram commutes:

fr:resource.fr:resource-source: \DiagramSquare { nw = TUX_\bullet , sw = UX_\bullet , se = {\mathopen {}\left \{UZ\right \}\mathclose {}}, ne = {\mathopen {}\left \{TUY\right \}\mathclose {}}, north = TUy_\bullet , west = \alpha _{X_\bullet }, south = Uz_\bullet , east = \alpha _Y;h, width = 2.5cm, }

html:li.html:p: This holds immediately from the homomorphism property of y_\bullet .
Second, we must check that the following diagram commutes:

fr:resource.fr:resource-source: \DiagramSquare { nw = TUX_\bullet , sw = UX_\bullet , se = {\mathopen {}\left \{UZ\right \}\mathclose {}}, ne = {\mathopen {}\left \{TUY\right \}\mathclose {}}, north = TUy_\bullet , west = \alpha _{X_\bullet }, south = Uz_\bullet , east = Th;\alpha _Z, width = 2.5cm, }

html:li.html:p: This follows from the factorization Uy_\bullet ;h=Uz_\bullet and the homomorphism property of z_\bullet .

fr:title.text: Creation of colimits by the forgetful functor

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Creation of colimits by the forgetful functor

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let \mathcal {C} be a category and let \mathbb {T} = {\mathopen {}\left (T,\eta ,\mu \right )\mathclose {}} be a monad on \mathcal {C}, writing {\mathcal {C}^{\mathbb {T}}}\xrightarrow {{U}}{\mathcal {C}} for the forgetful functor from the Eilenberg–Moore category \mathcal {C}^{\mathbb {T}}. If T preserves colimits of \mathcal {I}-figures for a given small category \mathcal {I}, then {\mathcal {C}^{\mathbb {T}}}\xrightarrow {{U}}{\mathcal {C}} creates colimits of \mathcal {I}-figures.

Let {\mathcal {I}}\xrightarrow {{X_\bullet }}{\mathcal {C}^{\mathbb {T}}} be a diagram such that \mathcal {I}\xrightarrow {X_\bullet }\mathcal {C}^{\mathbb {T}}\xrightarrow {U}\mathcal {C} has a (co)limit cocone {UX_\bullet }\xrightarrow {{c_\bullet }}{{\mathopen {}\left \{C\right \}\mathclose {}}}. Let \bar {C}={\mathopen {}\left (C,\alpha _{\bar {C}}\right )\mathclose {}} be the canonical algebra structure on the colimit apex C such that {UX_\bullet }\xrightarrow {{c_\bullet }}{{\mathopen {}\left \{C\right \}\mathclose {}}} lifts to a cocone of algebras. Then we conclude that this cocone is universal because U reflects colimits of \mathcal {I}-figures. It is evident (by definition) that U preserves this colimit.
A dcpo is called pointed when it has a bottom element \bot under the information order.

fr:title.text: Suprema of semidirected subsets in pointed dcpos

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Suprema of semidirected subsets in pointed dcpos

fr:mainmatter.html:p: A dcpo A is pointed if and only if it is closed under suprema of semidirected subsets.

Suppose that A is closed under suprema of semidirected subsets. In particular, we may consider the supremum \bigsqcup {\mathopen {}\left \{\right \}\mathclose {}} of the empty set. This is evidently the bottom element, using the universal property of the supremum.

Conversely, suppose that A is pointed and let I\subseteq A be semidirected. We may replace I\subseteq A by the directed subset I' = I\cup {\mathopen {}\left \{\bot \right \}\mathclose {}}; the inclusion I\subseteq I' is clearly cofinal, so the supremum of I' is also the supremum of I.
A pointed dcpo carries a (unique) \mathbb {L}-algebra structure.

The algebra structure is unique if it exists because \mathbb {L} is a Kock–Zöberlein monad, i.e. a monad for which the structure maps of algebras are left adjoint to the unit in the order-enrichment. Therefore, it suffices to show that there merely exists an algebra structure {\mathsf {L}{A}}\xrightarrow {{\alpha }}{A} for any pointed dcpo A.

We define the structure map \alpha to take u\in \mathsf {L}{A} to the supremum of the semidirected subset {\mathopen {}\left \{x\in A \mid u = \eta _Ax\right \}\mathclose {}}, so we may write \alpha u = \bigsqcup _{p:u{\downarrow }}u[p]. It is not difficult to see that this assignment is continuous.
The unit law for the algebra is trivial. The multiplication law is verified as follows:
Let {\mathopen {}\left (A,\alpha \right )\mathclose {}} be a \mathbb {L}-algebra; then the underlying dcpo A is pointed.

To define the bottom element of A, we choose \alpha {\mathopen {}\left (\bot , \lambda \_.\star \right )\mathclose {}}. Fixing n\in A, we must check that \alpha {\mathopen {}\left (\bot , \lambda \_.\star \right )\mathclose {}}\sqsubseteq n. Because \mathsf {L} is a Kock–Zöberlein monad and thus we have \alpha \dashv \eta _{A}, it is equivalent to observe that {\mathopen {}\left (\bot , \lambda \_.\star \right )\mathclose {}}\sqsubseteq \eta _{A}n.

Let {\mathopen {}\left (A,\alpha \right )\mathclose {}} and {\mathopen {}\left (B,\beta \right )\mathclose {}} be two \mathbb {L}-algebras; then a morphism of dcpos {A}\xrightarrow {{f}}{B} is a homomorphism of algebras if and only if it preserves the bottom element.

It is clear that a homomorphism of algebras must preserve the bottom element. On the other hand, suppose that {A}\xrightarrow {{f}}{B} preserves the bottom element to check that the following diagram commutes:

fr:resource.fr:resource-source: \DiagramSquare { nw = TA, ne = TB, sw = A, se = B, north = Tf, south = f, west = \alpha , east = \beta , }

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Because both composites preserve the bottom element, it is enough to observe that they both take u\in TA to the supremum of the following semidirected subset:

The category of \mathbb {L}-algebras and homomorphisms is (canonically) equivalent to the category of pointed dcpos and bottom-preserving morphisms of dcpos. It follows that pointed dcpos are monadic over dcpos.

Having a bottom element and being an algebra are both properties of dcpos, because these structures are uniquely determined. Therefore, we will argue that pointed dcpos with bottom-preserving morphisms form the same subcategory of \mathsf {dcpo} as the category of algebras with algebra-preserving maps. We have already seen that pointed structure and algebra structure are interchangeable:
To finish, we recall that a morphism of dcpos preserves algebra structure if and only if it preserves the bottom element.
By virtue of the monadicity result, we will refer to pointed dcpos and \mathbb {L}-algebras interchangeably.

We will deduce the closure of \mathsf {dcpo}^{\mathbb {L}} under connected colimits using general results about monads. Then we use the results of Linton to deduce the cocompleteness of \mathsf {dcpo}^{\mathbb {L}}. Note that the proof establishing that the lift monad preserves connected colimits has an error in it. I have a fix for it, suggested by Ohad Kammar, but I haven't written it down yet here.
For any dcpo A, the following is a co-comma square in the posetal 2-category of dcpos, where \mathsf {L} takes a dcpo to its lift or Scott-open partial map classifier.

fr:resource.fr:resource-source: \begin {tikzpicture}[diagram] \SpliceDiagramSquare { nw = A, sw = A, ne = \mathbf {1}_{}, se = \mathsf {L}{A}, north = !_{A}, east = \bot , east/style = embedding, south/style = embedding, south = \eta _A, west/style = double, } \node [between = nw and se] {$\sqsupseteq $}; \end {tikzpicture}

fr:mainmatter.html:p: We fix another lax square of the following form:
We must show that there exists a unique morphism \mathsf {L}{A}\xrightarrow {d}D factoring the square above through {\mathopen {}\left \{d_\bot \sqsubseteq d_A\right \}\mathclose {}} as follows:

We will define \mathsf {L}{A}\xrightarrow {d}D to take a^{?}:\mathsf {L}{A} to the least upper bound of the directed subset U = {\mathopen {}\left \{d_\bot \right \}\mathclose {}}\cup {\mathopen {}\left \{d_A a\mid a^{?}=\eta _Aa\right \}\mathclose {}}\subseteq D. As this assignment evidently has the correct factorization property, it remains just to check that it is continuous. Letting V be a directed subset of \mathsf {L}{A}, we compute:
For uniqueness, suppose that we have two morphisms \mathsf {L}{A}\xrightarrow {d,d'}D factoring our square in the sense described above and fix a^{?}:\mathsf {L}{A}:
Let A_\bullet be a diagram of dcpos indexed in a connected category \mathcal {I}. Then the lifting endofunctor \mathsf {L} on dcpos preserves the colimit of A_\bullet .

Let A_\bullet \xrightarrow {\iota _\bullet }{\mathopen {}\left \{A_\infty \right \}\mathclose {}} be a universal cocone; we must show that \mathsf {L}{A_\bullet }\xrightarrow {\mathsf {L}{\iota _\bullet }}{\mathopen {}\left \{\mathsf {L}{A_\infty }\right \}\mathclose {}} is universal as well, i.e. show any cocone \mathsf {L}{A_\bullet }\xrightarrow {d_\bullet }{\mathopen {}\left \{D\right \}\mathclose {}} factors uniquely through \mathsf {L}{A_\bullet }\xrightarrow {\mathsf {L}{\iota _\bullet }}{\mathopen {}\left \{\mathsf {L}{A_\infty }\right \}\mathclose {}} in the following sense:

Using the universal property of \mathsf {L}{A_\infty } as a co-comma dcpo, we may define \mathsf {L}{A_\infty }\xrightarrow {d_\infty }D to be the universal map determined by a certain lax square in the following configuration:

fr:resource.fr:resource-source: \begin {tikzpicture}[diagram] \SpliceDiagramSquare <sq/>{ nw = A_\infty , sw = A_\infty , ne = \mathbf {1}_{}, se = D, north = !_{A_\infty }, east = {h_\bot }, east/style = {exists,->}, south/style = {exists,->}, south = {h_{A_\infty }}, west/style = double, } \node [between = sq/nw and sq/se] {$\sqsupseteq $}; \end {tikzpicture}

fr:mainmatter.html:p: First we define {\mathbf {1}_{}}\xrightarrow {{h_\bot }}{D} to be the element d_i\bot determined by an arbitrary object i\in \mathcal {I}. To see that this is well-defined, fix i,j\in \mathcal {I} to check that d_i\bot =d_j\bot . As \mathcal {I} is connected, we may proceed by induction on a zigzag i\leadsto j\in \mathcal {I}; ultimately, this amounts to checking that for any span i\leftarrow k \rightarrow j in \mathcal {I}, we have d_i\bot =d_k\bot =d_j\bot . This follows from the strictness of lifted morphisms as well as the naturality of the cocone d_\bullet .
Next we define {A_\infty }\xrightarrow {{h_{A_\infty }}}{D} using the universal property of the colimiting cocone {A_\bullet }\xrightarrow {{\iota _\bullet }}{A_\infty }:

fr:resource.fr:resource-source: \DiagramSquare { nw = A_\bullet , sw = \mathsf {L}{A_\bullet }, ne = {\mathopen {}\left \{A_\infty \right \}\mathclose {}}, se = {\mathopen {}\left \{D\right \}\mathclose {}}, west/style = embedding, west = \eta _{A_\bullet }, north = \iota _\bullet , south = d_\bullet , east/style = {exists,->}, east = \exists !{\mathopen {}\left \{h_{A_\infty }\right \}\mathclose {}}, }

fr:mainmatter.html:p: To arrange h_{A_\infty } and h_\bot into the desired lax square, we must check that for all a_\infty :A_\infty we have h_\bot \sqsubseteq h_{A_\infty }a_\infty . Fixing arbitrary i\in \mathcal {I} and a\in A_i, it suffices to check that h_\bot \sqsubseteq h_{A_\infty }\iota _{i}a. As h_\bot =d_i\bot and h_{A_\infty }\iota _ia = d_i\eta _{A_i}a, our goal follows directly from the monotonicity of {\mathsf {L}{A_i}}\xrightarrow {{d_i}}{D}.

html:p.html:mark: The reasoning above is not correct, we do not know that we can restrict attention to a\in A_i. This is indeed the case, but need to make it explicit.

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Thus we have the desired lax square and a unique morphism {\mathsf {L}{A_\infty }}\xrightarrow {{h}}{D} factoring it through the co-comma square that defines \mathsf {L}{A_\infty }:

Our goal is to show that we may choose the universal map {\mathsf {L}{A_\infty }}\xrightarrow {{d_\infty }}{D} corresponding to the cocone {\mathsf {L}{A_\bullet }}\xrightarrow {{d_\bullet }}{{\mathopen {}\left \{D\right \}\mathclose {}}} to be the morphism h defined above. First we must prove that the following triangle commutes:
Using the universal property of the co-comma squares for each \mathsf {L}{A_i}, it suffices to check that two diagrams commute:

html:li.html:p: We must check that the outer triangle below commutes:
Rewriting using the strictness of lifted morphisms, this amounts to the established fact that h\bot = h_\bot .
We must check that the outer triangle below commutes:
Rewriting with established equations, it suffices to observe that the outer diagram below commutes:

html:ol.html:p: Finally, we must check that any two morphisms {\mathsf {L}{A_\infty }}\xrightarrow {{k,k'}}{D} factoring {\mathsf {L}{A_\bullet }}\xrightarrow {{d_\bullet }}{{\mathopen {}\left \{D\right \}\mathclose {}}} through {\mathsf {L}{A_\bullet }}\xrightarrow {{\mathsf {L}{\iota _\bullet }}}{{\mathopen {}\left \{\mathsf {L}{A_\infty }\right \}\mathclose {}}} are equal. To that end, we will use the universal property of the co-comma square defining \mathsf {L}{A_\infty } once more to reduce this to checking that k,k' agree on \bot and on \eta _{A_\bullet }. The former follows directly from the strictness of \mathsf {L}{\iota _\bullet }, as we have k\bot = k{\mathopen {}\left (\mathsf {L} \iota _\bullet \bot \right )\mathclose {}}=d_\bullet \bot . For the latter, we must check that k\circ \eta _{A_\infty }=k'\circ \eta _{A_\infty }; by the universal property of the colimiting cocone {A_\bullet }\xrightarrow {{\iota _\bullet }}{A_\infty }, it suffices to check that k\circ \eta _{A_\infty }\circ \iota _\bullet = k'\circ \eta _{A_\infty }\circ \iota _\bullet . By naturality of the unit, these are both equal to d_\bullet \circ \eta _{A_\bullet }.

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let \mathbb {L}={\mathopen {}\left (\mathsf {L},\eta ,\mu \right )\mathclose {}} be the lifting monad on dcpos; the Eilenberg–Moore category \mathsf {dcpo}^{\mathbb {L}} is closed under connected colimits, and these colimits are created by the forgetful functor {\mathsf {dcpo}^{\mathbb {L}}}\xrightarrow {{\mathsf {U}^{\mathbb {L}}}}{\mathsf {dcpo}}.
This follows from the following facts:

html:ol.html:li: The category of dcpos is (even constructively) known to be cocomplete.
Lifting preserves connected colimits.
The forgetful functor {\mathsf {dcpo}^{\mathbb {L}}}\xrightarrow {{\mathsf {U}^{\mathbb {L}}}}{\mathsf {dcpo}} creates whatever colimits \mathsf {L} preserves.

fr:mainmatter.html:p: The Eilenberg–Moore category \mathsf {dcpo}^{\mathbb {L}} for the lifting monad \mathbb {L}={\mathopen {}\left (\mathsf {L},\eta ,\mu \right )\mathclose {}} on dcpos has all small coproducts.
This is the first part of Corollary 2 of Linton's Coequalizers in categories of algebras.

The coproduct of lift-algebras is computed as a reflexive coequalizer, whose existence we have already established. Given an index set I and a diagram {I}\xrightarrow {{X_{\bullet }}}{\mathsf {dcpo}^{\mathbb {L}}}, the colimit of the following reflexive pair is the coproduct of {I}\xrightarrow {{X_{\bullet }}}{\mathsf {dcpo}^{\mathbb {L}}} as shown by Linton:

fr:title.text: The category of lift-algebras is cocomplete

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: The category of lift-algebras is cocomplete

fr:mainmatter.html:p: The Eilenberg–Moore category \mathsf {dcpo}^{\mathbb {L}} for the lifting monad \mathbb {L}={\mathopen {}\left (\mathsf {L},\eta ,\mu \right )\mathclose {}} on dcpos is cocomplete.
This follows because \mathsf {dcpo}^{\mathbb {L}} under connected colimits and coproducts
These notes were prepared by Jon Sterling, based in part on discussions with Martín Hötzel Escardó and Tom de Jong. Any errors belong to Jon Sterling.

fr:title.text: The positive elements of a pointed dcpo

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: The positive elements of a pointed dcpo

fr:mainmatter.html:p: An element u of a pointed dpco A is called positive when for any semidirected subset I\subseteq A, if u\sqsubseteq \bigsqcup {I} then I is inhabited. We will write \mathsf {pos}\,{u} to mean that u is a positive element.
(This is adapted from Johnstone’s definition of positive elements of frames to the case of dcpos by Tom de Jong.)

fr:title.text: The bottom element is not positive

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: The bottom element is not positive

fr:mainmatter.html:p: The bottom element \bot of a pointed dcpo A is not positive.

Suppose that \bot was positive. The empty set {\mathopen {}\left \{\right \}\mathclose {}}\subseteq A is semidirected and \bot \sqsubseteq \bigsqcup {\mathopen {}\left \{\right \}\mathclose {}}=\bot , but nonetheless {\mathopen {}\left \{\right \}\mathclose {}} is not inhabited.
Let i\sqsubseteq j in a pointed dcpo A such that i is positive; then j is positive.

Fixing semidirected J\subseteq A such that j\sqsubseteq \bigsqcup {J}, we must show that J is inhabited. This follows from our assumption that i is positive becuase i\sqsubseteq j\sqsubseteq \bigsqcup {J}.

fr:title.text: Closure of positivity under directed suprema

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Closure of positivity under directed suprema

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let A be a pointed dcpo; the positivity predicate {\Gamma A}\xrightarrow {{\mathsf {pos}}}{\Omega } is closed under directed suprema.

Let J\subseteq A be a directed subset such that every u\in J is positive; we must show that \bigsqcup {J} is positive. Fixing a subdirected subset I\subseteq A such that \bigsqcup {J}\sqsubseteq \bigsqcup I, we must check that I is inhabited. The inequality \bigsqcup {J}\sqsubseteq \bigsqcup I holds if and only if u\sqsubseteq \bigsqcup {I} for all u\in u; as J is directed, we therefore have some positive u\in A such that u\sqsubseteq \bigsqcup {I} from which it follows that I is inhabited.

fr:title.text: The subdcpo spanned by positive elements

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: The subdcpo spanned by positive elements

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let A be a pointed dcpo; then the subposet A^+\subseteq A spanned by positive is a dcpo.
This follows from the closure of positive elements in an algebra under directed suprema.

fr:title.text: The positive part of a semidirected subset is semidirected

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: The positive part of a semidirected subset is semidirected

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let I\subseteq A be a semidirected subset of a pointed dcpo A; then the intersection I \cap A^+ is semidirected, where A^+ is the subdcpo spanned by positive elements.

Let i,j be two positive elements of I; we must show that there exists a positive element k\in I such that i\sqsubseteq k and j\sqsubseteq k. This follows immediately from the directedness of I and the fact that positivity is monotone.

fr:title.text: Positivity = definedness in a lifted dcpo

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Positivity = definedness in a lifted dcpo

fr:mainmatter.html:p: The positive elements of a lifted dcpo \mathsf {L}{A} are exactly the defined elements, i.e. those lying in the image of {A}\xrightarrow {{\eta }}{\mathsf {L}{A}}.

Let a\in A be an element of the dcpo A. To show that \eta _A a is positive, we fix a semidirected subset U\subseteq \mathsf {L}{A} such that \eta _A a\sqsubseteq \bigsqcup U to show that U is inhabited. The inequality implies that \top \sqsubseteq \exists u\in U. u{\downarrow }, so we know that U is inhabited.

Conversely, suppose that u\in \mathsf {L}{A} is a positive element. Let U be the semidirected family {\mathopen {}\left \{v \mid v = u \land u\downarrow \right \}\mathclose {}}; we evidently have u\sqsubseteq \bigsqcup {U}, so U is inhabited. Thus it follows that u is defined.

fr:title.text: Characterization of positivity in terms of partial elements

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Characterization of positivity in terms of partial elements

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let A be a pointed dcpo. Then an element a:A is positive if and only if for any partial element u: LA such that a\sqsubseteq \bigsqcup _{p:u{\downarrow }}u[p], we have u{\downarrow }=\top .

Therefore, we first suppose that any u: LA is defined supposing a\sqsubseteq \bigsqcup _{p:u{\downarrow }}u[p] to check that a is positive. Fixing a semidirected subset I\subseteq A such that a\sqsubseteq \bigsqcup {I}, we must show that I is inhabited. We consider the partial element u={\mathopen {}\left (\exists i\in I. \top , \lambda \_.\bigsqcup {I}\right )\mathclose {}}:LA, and observe that \bigsqcup {I}=\bigsqcup _{i\in I} \bigsqcup {I}=\bigsqcup _{p:u{\downarrow }}u[p], and so we have a\sqsubseteq \bigsqcup _{p:u{\downarrow }}u[p] and thus it follows that u{\downarrow }=\top and so I is inhabited.

Conversely, if a is positive, it follows that any partial element u is defined when a\sqsubseteq \bigsqcup _{p:u{\downarrow }}u[p], because the subset {\mathopen {}\left \{y\mid y=a\land u{\downarrow }\right \}\mathclose {}} is semidirected.

It follows from our characterization of positivity in terms of partial elements that an element a: A of a pointed dcpo A is positive if and only if it is strictly above the bottom element, i.e. \bot \sqsubset a.
(See also Proposition 6.2.12 of Tom de Jong’s thesis.)

So far we have studied positivity as an order-theoretic property of domains; in this section, we explore a non-order-theoretic generalization of this condition that is applicable in the setting of axiomatic domain theory. This notion is inspired by the alternative characterization positivity in terms of partial elements.

fr:title.text: The Sierpiński interval of a dominion

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: The Sierpiński interval of a dominion

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let \mathcal {C} be a category with pullbacks, a terminal object and let \mathcal {M} be a dominion on \mathcal {C}. A Sierpiński space for \mathcal {M} is defined to be a universal \mathcal {M}-partial map, i.e. a morphism {\mathbf {1}_{\mathcal {C}}}\xrightarrow {{\top }}{\Sigma }\in \mathcal {M} such that for any {U}\xrightarrow {{i}}{A}\in \mathcal {M} there exists a unique map {A}\xrightarrow {{\chi _i}}{\Sigma } making the following square cartesian:

fr:resource.fr:resource-source: \DiagramSquare { ne = \mathbf {1}_{\mathcal {C}}, se = \Sigma , east = \top \in \mathcal {M}, sw = A, nw = U, west = \mathcal {M}\ni i, south = \chi _i, south/style = {->,exists}, west/style = >->, east/style = >->, nw/style = pullback, }

fr:mainmatter.html:p: When \mathcal {C} has an initial object \mathbf {0}_{\mathcal {C}} and every {\mathbf {0}_{\mathcal {C}}}\xrightarrow {{}}{A} lies in \mathcal {M}, the Sierpiński space becomes an “interval object” {\mathopen {}\left (\Sigma ,\top ,\bot \right )\mathclose {}} where {\mathbf {1}_{\mathcal {C}}}\xrightarrow {{\bot }}{\Sigma } is given as follows:

fr:resource.fr:resource-source: \DiagramSquare { ne = \mathbf {1}_{\mathcal {C}}, se = \Sigma , east = \top , sw = \mathbf {1}_{\mathcal {C}}, nw = \mathbf {0}_{\mathcal {C}}, south = \bot , south/style = {->,exists}, west/style = >->, east/style = >->, nw/style = pullback, }

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Under these circumstances, we refer to \mathcal {M} as a dominion that has a Sierpiński interval.

Let \mathcal {C} be category with pullbacks, a terminal object, and an initial object, equipped with a dominion \mathcal {M} that has a Sierpiński interval {\mathopen {}\left (\Sigma ,\top ,\bot \right )\mathclose {}}. A path from {I}\xrightarrow {{f}}{C} to {I}\xrightarrow {{g}}{C} in \mathcal {C} is defined to be a morphism {\Sigma \times I}\xrightarrow {{p}}{C} such that the following diagram commutes:
We shall write p:f\leadsto g to denote a path from f to g.

Let \mathcal {C} be category with pullbacks, a terminal object, and an initial object, equipped with a dominion \mathcal {M} that has a Sierpiński interval {\mathopen {}\left (\Sigma ,\top ,\bot \right )\mathclose {}}, such that \mathcal {M}-partial map classifiers LA exist for all A\in \mathcal {C}. We will write \mathbb {L}={\mathopen {}\left (L,\eta ,\mu \right )\mathclose {}} for the resulting partial map classifier monad on \mathcal {C}.

Let {\mathopen {}\left (A,\alpha \right )\mathclose {}} be an \mathbb {L}-algebra in \mathcal {C}, and let {C}\xrightarrow {{x}}{A} be a generalized element of A. We say that {C}\xrightarrow {{x}}{A} is positive when for any {C}\xrightarrow {{u}}{LA} such that there exists a path from {C}\xrightarrow {{x}}{A} to {C}\xrightarrow {{u;\alpha }}{A}, then {C}\xrightarrow {{u}}{LA} factors through some (necessarily unique) {C}\xrightarrow {{y}}{A} as below:

fr:title.text: The two notions of positivity coincide for pointed dcpos

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: The two notions of positivity coincide for pointed dcpos

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let A be a pointed dcpo. Then an element x:A is a positive element of the pointed dcpo if and only if {\mathbf {1}_{}}\xrightarrow {{x}}{A} is a positive element in the dominion \mathcal {O} of Scott-open immersions of dcpos.
We first observe that the latter condition is equivalent to the following:
fr:mainmatter.html:blockquote: For any u\in LA, if a\sqsubseteq \bigsqcup _{p: u{\downarrow }}u[p] then u{\downarrow }=\top .
fr:mainmatter.html:p: This follows from the (constructive) characterization of the path order in dcpos. Therefore, our result follows from our earlier characterization of positive elements of a pointed dcpo in terms of partial elements.

fr:title.text: Positive generation and open positivity predicates

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Positive generation and open positivity predicates

fr:mainmatter.html:p: In a lifted dcpo \mathsf {L}{A}, the positive elements form an open subdcpo {\mathopen {}\left (\mathsf {L}{A}\right )\mathclose {}}^+\cong A: thus, it follows that positivity is always an open property in classical mathematics. On the other hand, it seems that constructive mathematics does not necessarily assert that the positive elements form an open subspace in general. In this section, we grapple with this subtlety by studying the relationship between openness of A^+ and a desirable property that we shall refer to as positive generation, which states that every element of A is the supremum of its “positive part”.
We say that a pointed dcpo A has an open positivity predicate if and only if any of the following equivalent conditions hold:

html:ol.html:li: The positivity predicate {\Gamma A}\xrightarrow {{\mathsf {pos}}}{\Omega } tracks a continuous morphism of dcpos {A}\xrightarrow {{\mathsf {pos}}}{\Sigma }.
The embedding {A^+}\xrightarrow {{\iota ^+}}{A} is a Scott-open immersion.
For a directed subset I\subseteq A, if \bigsqcup {A} is positive then there exists an element a\in I that is positive in A.

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let A be a dcpo; then an element a:A is called positively generated when it is the supremum of the semidirected subset {\mathopen {}\left \{b:A\mid b=a\land \mathsf {pos}\,{a}\right \}\mathclose {}}, i.e. we have a \sqsubseteq \bigsqcup _{p:\mathsf {pos}\,a}a.
An element a of a pointed dcpo A is called non-negatively generated when a \sqsubseteq \bigsqcup _{\lnot {\mathopen {}\left (a=\bot \right )\mathclose {}}}a holds.

fr:title.text: Positively generated elements are non-negatively generated

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Positively generated elements are non-negatively generated

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let a be a positively generated element of a pointed dcpo A. Then a is also non-negatively generated.

We must check that a\sqsubseteq \bigsqcup _{p:\lnot {\mathopen {}\left (a = \bot \right )\mathclose {}}}a. By assumption, it suffices to check that \bigsqcup _{p:\mathsf {pos}\,a}a\sqsubseteq \bigsqcup _{p:\lnot {\mathopen {}\left (a=\bot \right )\mathclose {}}}a, which follows because the bottom element is not positive.

fr:title.text: Bottom and non-bottom elements are non-negatively generated

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Bottom and non-bottom elements are non-negatively generated

fr:mainmatter.html:p: In a pointed dcpo, any non-bottom element is non-negatively generated.

html:ol.html:li: The bottom element \bot .
Any compact element a:A for which \lnot {\mathopen {}\left (a=\bot \right )\mathclose {}} holds.

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Hence, any element a for which it is decidable whether a=\bot is non-negatively generated.

The bottom element is clearly non-negatively generated, as it lies beneath any element. Now fix a:A and assume \lnot {\mathopen {}\left (a=\bot \right )\mathclose {}}; we must check that a \sqsubseteq \bigsqcup _{p:\lnot {\mathopen {}\left (a=\bot \right )\mathclose {}}}a but the latter is equal to a.
When a pointed dcpo A satisfies either of the following equivalent conditions, we will refer to it as positively generated.

html:ol.html:li: Every element a: A is positively generated, i.e. we have a = \bigsqcup _{p:\mathsf {pos}\,a}a.
For any semidirected subset I\subseteq A, we have \bigsqcup I = \bigsqcup {\mathopen {}\left \{a\in I \mid \mathsf {pos}\,a\right \}\mathclose {}}.

fr:mainmatter.html:p: (2) implies (1) by setting I = {\mathopen {}\left \{a\right \}\mathclose {}}. Conversely, assume that each element is the supremum of its positive part and fix a semidirected subset I\subseteq A. We compute:
fr:mainmatter.fr:tex: \bigsqcup {\mathopen {}\left \{a \in I \mid \mathsf {pos}\,a\right \}\mathclose {}} = \bigsqcup _{a\in {\mathopen {}\left \{a \in I\mid \mathsf {pos}\,a\right \}\mathclose {}}}a = \bigsqcup _{a\in I}\bigsqcup _{p\in \mathsf {pos}\,a} a = \bigsqcup _{a\in I} a

fr:title.text: Positively generated dcpos have open positivity predicates

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Positively generated dcpos have open positivity predicates

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let A be a positively generated pointed dcpo. Then A has an open positivity predicate.

Let I\subseteq A be a directed subset such that \bigsqcup {I} is positive; we must find a positive element of I. Because A is positively generated we know that \bigsqcup {I} \sqsubseteq \bigsqcup {\mathopen {}\left (I\cap A^+\right )\mathclose {}}. Because \bigsqcup {I} is positive and I\cap A^+ is semidirected, it follows that the latter is inhabited.
Let A be a dcpo; then the lift \mathsf {L}{A} is positively generated.

Let u={\mathopen {}\left (\phi ,a\right )\mathclose {}} be an element of \mathsf {L}{A}. Note that u is equal to \bigsqcup _{p:\phi }u; as definedness coincides with positivity in lifted dcpos, we have \phi = \mathsf {pos}\,u, and so we are done.

fr:title.text: Lifted dcpos have open positivity predicates

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Lifted dcpos have open positivity predicates

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let A be a dcpo; then the lifting \mathsf {L}{A} has an open positivity predicate.
It suffices to recall that a lifted dcpo is positively generated.

fr:title.text: When is a continuous pointed dcpo positively generated?

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: When is a continuous pointed dcpo positively generated?

fr:mainmatter.html:p: We describe some light conditions under which a continuous dcpo is positively generated.

fr:title.text: Non-negatively generated basis yields positive generation

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Non-negatively generated basis yields positive generation

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let A be a pointed continuous dcpo presented by a basis B\subseteq A such that each element of B is non-negatively generated in A. Then A is positively generated.

We must show that for any a\in A, we have a \sqsubseteq \bigsqcup _{p:\mathsf {pos}\,a}a. Let B_a be the subset {\mathopen {}\left \{b \in B \mid b\ll a\right \}\mathclose {}}. By assumption, it suffices to check that \bigsqcup B_a \sqsubseteq \bigsqcup _{p:\mathsf {pos}\,a}a. Fixing b\in B_a, we must check that b\sqsubseteq \bigsqcup _{p:\mathsf {pos}\,a}a.

As b is assumed to be non-negatively generated, we have b=\bigsqcup _{p:\lnot {\mathopen {}\left (b=\bot \right )\mathclose {}}}b so to check b\sqsubseteq \bigsqcup _{p:\mathsf {pos}\,a}a it suffices to check that \lnot {\mathopen {}\left (b=\bot \right )\mathclose {}} implies that a is positive. We fix semidirected J\subseteq A such that a\sqsubseteq \bigsqcup {J} = \bigsqcup {\mathopen {}\left ({\mathopen {}\left \{\bot \right \}\mathclose {}}\cup J\right )\mathclose {}} to check that J is inhabited. We recall that b\ll a and a\sqsubseteq \bigsqcup {\mathopen {}\left ({\mathopen {}\left \{\bot \right \}\mathclose {}}\cup J\right )\mathclose {}}, so it follows by the definition of the way-below relation that either b\sqsubseteq \bot or there exists j\in J such that b\sqsubseteq j. The first case is contradictory by our assumption that \lnot {\mathopen {}\left (b=\bot \right )\mathclose {}}, and the second case verifies that J is inhabited, so a is positive.

fr:title.text: Basis with decidable bottomhood yields positive generation

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Basis with decidable bottomhood yields positive generation

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let A be a pointed continuous dcpo presented by a basis B\subseteq A for each element b\in B it is decidable whether b=\bot . Then A is positively generated.
We observe that every element of B is non-negatively generated, so we may conclude that A is positively generated.

fr:title.text: Positively generated basis yields positive generation

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Positively generated basis yields positive generation

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let A be a pointed continuous dcpo presented by a basis B\subseteq A whose elements are all positively generated in A. Then A is positively generated.
As positive generation implies non-negative generation for an element of a pointed dcpo, we may conclude that A is positively generated.
I am not sure how useful the following construction is. On the other hand, maybe it has a universal property at the level of posets.

fr:title.text: The positively generated core of a dcpo

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: The positively generated core of a dcpo

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let A be a pointed dcpo; the subposet A^{\mathit {pg}}\subseteq {A} spanned by positively generated elements is closed under directed suprema, and thus gives rise to a subdcpo that we shall refer to as the positively generated core of A.

Let I\subseteq A be a directed subset whose elements are all positively generated. We must check that the supremum \bigsqcup {I} is positively generated, i.e. \bigsqcup {I} \sqsubseteq \bigsqcup _{p:\mathsf {pos}\,\bigsqcup {I}}\bigsqcup {I}. Fixing i\in I, we must check that i\sqsubseteq \bigsqcup _{p:\mathsf {pos}\,{\bigsqcup {I}}}\bigsqcup {I}. As i is positively generated, we have i\sqsubseteq \bigsqcup _{p:\mathsf {pos}\,{i}}i. As positivity is upward-closed, we have \mathsf {pos}\,{i}\sqsubseteq \mathsf {pos}\,\bigsqcup {I}. Therefore, we deduce i\sqsubseteq \bigsqcup _{p:\mathsf {pos}\,i}i \sqsubseteq \bigsqcup _{p:\mathsf {pos}\,{\bigsqcup {I}}}\bigsqcup {I}.

fr:title.text: Characterizing freeness in terms of positivity

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Characterizing freeness in terms of positivity

fr:mainmatter.html:p: In classical mathematics, every \mathbb {L}-algebra is free; this does not appear to be asserted by constructive mathematics, but in this section we verify that freeness can be characterized in terms of positivity. The main result is that a pointed dcpo A is positively generated if and only the evident map {\mathsf {L}{A^+}}\xrightarrow {{}}{A} is an isomorphism.

Let A be a pointed dcpo with an open positivity predicate; we define the “purification” map {A}\xrightarrow {{\mathsf {purify}_A}}{\mathsf {L}{A^+}} into the lift of the subdcpo of positive elements to send a\in A to the partial element {\mathopen {}\left (\mathsf {pos}\,{a},\lambda p. a\right )\mathclose {}}; we note:
The mapping defined above is continuous because we have assumed that A has an open positivity predicate, so its domain of definition defines a Scott-open subdcpo of A.

fr:title.text: Pointed dcpos with open positivity predicates are almost free

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Pointed dcpos with open positivity predicates are almost free

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let A be a pointed dcpo with an open positivity predicate; then the purification map {A}\xrightarrow {{\mathsf {purify}_A}}{\mathsf {L}{A^+}} is the projection part of an embedding-projection pair {\mathopen {}\left (\mathsf {L}{\iota ^+};\alpha _A\right )\mathclose {}}\dashv \mathsf {purify}_A.

We fix {\mathopen {}\left (\phi ,a^+\right )\mathclose {}}: \mathsf {L}{A^+} and compute explicitly using the fact that \mathsf {purify}_A preserves the bottom element and therefore preserves semidirected subsets:

For the deflation, we fix a:A and observe that
\alpha _A{\mathopen {}\left (\mathsf {L}{\iota ^+}{\mathopen {}\left (\mathsf {purify}_A a\right )\mathclose {}}\right )\mathclose {}} = \bigsqcup _{p:\mathsf {pos}\,a} a which is evidently below a.

fr:title.text: Positively generated pointed dcpos are free

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Positively generated pointed dcpos are free

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let A be a positively generated pointed dcpo; then A is canonically free on its subdcpo of positive elements A^+. More specifically, the embedding-projection pair {\mathopen {}\left (\mathsf {L}{\iota ^+};\alpha _A\right )\mathclose {}}\dashv {A}\xrightarrow {{\mathsf {purify}_A}}{\mathsf {L}{A^+}} given by the purification map is an isomorphism of dcpos.

First, we recall that the embedding-projection pair {\mathopen {}\left (\mathsf {L}{\iota ^+};\alpha _A\right )\mathclose {}}\dashv \mathsf {purify}_A exists because A has an open positivity predicate by virtue of its positive generation. Therefore, the statement of this lemma is well-formed.

Because {\mathopen {}\left (\mathsf {L}{\iota ^+};\alpha _A\right )\mathclose {}}\dashv \mathsf {purify}_A is an embedding-projection pair, it remains only to check that \mathsf {purify}_A;\mathsf {L}{\iota ^+};\alpha _A is an inflation, i.e. for all a:A we must have a \sqsubseteq \alpha _A{\mathopen {}\left (\mathsf {L}{\iota ^+}{\mathopen {}\left (\mathsf {purify}_Aa\right )\mathclose {}}\right )\mathclose {}}. As the latter is equal to \bigsqcup _{p:\mathsf {pos}\,a}a, the inflation condition follows from our assumption that A is positively generated.
A pointed dcpo A is lifted if and only if it is positively generated.
This follows from two existing lemmas:

html:ol.html:li: Lifted dcpos (free algebras) are positively generated.
Positively generated pointed dcpos are free.

fr:mainmatter.html:p: We will deduce the closure of \mathsf {dcpo}^{\mathbb {L}} under connected colimits using general results about monads. Then we use the results of Linton to deduce the cocompleteness of \mathsf {dcpo}^{\mathbb {L}}. Note that the proof establishing that the lift monad preserves connected colimits has an error in it. I have a fix for it, suggested by Ohad Kammar, but I haven't written it down yet here.
For any dcpo A, the following is a co-comma square in the posetal 2-category of dcpos, where \mathsf {L} takes a dcpo to its lift or Scott-open partial map classifier.

fr:resource.fr:resource-source: \begin {tikzpicture}[diagram] \SpliceDiagramSquare { nw = A, sw = A, ne = \mathbf {1}_{}, se = \mathsf {L}{A}, north = !_{A}, east = \bot , east/style = embedding, south/style = embedding, south = \eta _A, west/style = double, } \node [between = nw and se] {$\sqsupseteq $}; \end {tikzpicture}

fr:mainmatter.html:p: We fix another lax square of the following form:
We must show that there exists a unique morphism \mathsf {L}{A}\xrightarrow {d}D factoring the square above through {\mathopen {}\left \{d_\bot \sqsubseteq d_A\right \}\mathclose {}} as follows:

We will define \mathsf {L}{A}\xrightarrow {d}D to take a^{?}:\mathsf {L}{A} to the least upper bound of the directed subset U = {\mathopen {}\left \{d_\bot \right \}\mathclose {}}\cup {\mathopen {}\left \{d_A a\mid a^{?}=\eta _Aa\right \}\mathclose {}}\subseteq D. As this assignment evidently has the correct factorization property, it remains just to check that it is continuous. Letting V be a directed subset of \mathsf {L}{A}, we compute:
For uniqueness, suppose that we have two morphisms \mathsf {L}{A}\xrightarrow {d,d'}D factoring our square in the sense described above and fix a^{?}:\mathsf {L}{A}:
Let A_\bullet be a diagram of dcpos indexed in a connected category \mathcal {I}. Then the lifting endofunctor \mathsf {L} on dcpos preserves the colimit of A_\bullet .

Let A_\bullet \xrightarrow {\iota _\bullet }{\mathopen {}\left \{A_\infty \right \}\mathclose {}} be a universal cocone; we must show that \mathsf {L}{A_\bullet }\xrightarrow {\mathsf {L}{\iota _\bullet }}{\mathopen {}\left \{\mathsf {L}{A_\infty }\right \}\mathclose {}} is universal as well, i.e. show any cocone \mathsf {L}{A_\bullet }\xrightarrow {d_\bullet }{\mathopen {}\left \{D\right \}\mathclose {}} factors uniquely through \mathsf {L}{A_\bullet }\xrightarrow {\mathsf {L}{\iota _\bullet }}{\mathopen {}\left \{\mathsf {L}{A_\infty }\right \}\mathclose {}} in the following sense:

Using the universal property of \mathsf {L}{A_\infty } as a co-comma dcpo, we may define \mathsf {L}{A_\infty }\xrightarrow {d_\infty }D to be the universal map determined by a certain lax square in the following configuration:

fr:resource.fr:resource-source: \begin {tikzpicture}[diagram] \SpliceDiagramSquare <sq/>{ nw = A_\infty , sw = A_\infty , ne = \mathbf {1}_{}, se = D, north = !_{A_\infty }, east = {h_\bot }, east/style = {exists,->}, south/style = {exists,->}, south = {h_{A_\infty }}, west/style = double, } \node [between = sq/nw and sq/se] {$\sqsupseteq $}; \end {tikzpicture}

fr:mainmatter.html:p: First we define {\mathbf {1}_{}}\xrightarrow {{h_\bot }}{D} to be the element d_i\bot determined by an arbitrary object i\in \mathcal {I}. To see that this is well-defined, fix i,j\in \mathcal {I} to check that d_i\bot =d_j\bot . As \mathcal {I} is connected, we may proceed by induction on a zigzag i\leadsto j\in \mathcal {I}; ultimately, this amounts to checking that for any span i\leftarrow k \rightarrow j in \mathcal {I}, we have d_i\bot =d_k\bot =d_j\bot . This follows from the strictness of lifted morphisms as well as the naturality of the cocone d_\bullet .
Next we define {A_\infty }\xrightarrow {{h_{A_\infty }}}{D} using the universal property of the colimiting cocone {A_\bullet }\xrightarrow {{\iota _\bullet }}{A_\infty }:

fr:resource.fr:resource-source: \DiagramSquare { nw = A_\bullet , sw = \mathsf {L}{A_\bullet }, ne = {\mathopen {}\left \{A_\infty \right \}\mathclose {}}, se = {\mathopen {}\left \{D\right \}\mathclose {}}, west/style = embedding, west = \eta _{A_\bullet }, north = \iota _\bullet , south = d_\bullet , east/style = {exists,->}, east = \exists !{\mathopen {}\left \{h_{A_\infty }\right \}\mathclose {}}, }

fr:mainmatter.html:p: To arrange h_{A_\infty } and h_\bot into the desired lax square, we must check that for all a_\infty :A_\infty we have h_\bot \sqsubseteq h_{A_\infty }a_\infty . Fixing arbitrary i\in \mathcal {I} and a\in A_i, it suffices to check that h_\bot \sqsubseteq h_{A_\infty }\iota _{i}a. As h_\bot =d_i\bot and h_{A_\infty }\iota _ia = d_i\eta _{A_i}a, our goal follows directly from the monotonicity of {\mathsf {L}{A_i}}\xrightarrow {{d_i}}{D}.

html:p.html:mark: The reasoning above is not correct, we do not know that we can restrict attention to a\in A_i. This is indeed the case, but need to make it explicit.

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Thus we have the desired lax square and a unique morphism {\mathsf {L}{A_\infty }}\xrightarrow {{h}}{D} factoring it through the co-comma square that defines \mathsf {L}{A_\infty }:

Our goal is to show that we may choose the universal map {\mathsf {L}{A_\infty }}\xrightarrow {{d_\infty }}{D} corresponding to the cocone {\mathsf {L}{A_\bullet }}\xrightarrow {{d_\bullet }}{{\mathopen {}\left \{D\right \}\mathclose {}}} to be the morphism h defined above. First we must prove that the following triangle commutes:
Using the universal property of the co-comma squares for each \mathsf {L}{A_i}, it suffices to check that two diagrams commute:

html:li.html:p: We must check that the outer triangle below commutes:
Rewriting using the strictness of lifted morphisms, this amounts to the established fact that h\bot = h_\bot .
We must check that the outer triangle below commutes:
Rewriting with established equations, it suffices to observe that the outer diagram below commutes:

html:ol.html:p: Finally, we must check that any two morphisms {\mathsf {L}{A_\infty }}\xrightarrow {{k,k'}}{D} factoring {\mathsf {L}{A_\bullet }}\xrightarrow {{d_\bullet }}{{\mathopen {}\left \{D\right \}\mathclose {}}} through {\mathsf {L}{A_\bullet }}\xrightarrow {{\mathsf {L}{\iota _\bullet }}}{{\mathopen {}\left \{\mathsf {L}{A_\infty }\right \}\mathclose {}}} are equal. To that end, we will use the universal property of the co-comma square defining \mathsf {L}{A_\infty } once more to reduce this to checking that k,k' agree on \bot and on \eta _{A_\bullet }. The former follows directly from the strictness of \mathsf {L}{\iota _\bullet }, as we have k\bot = k{\mathopen {}\left (\mathsf {L} \iota _\bullet \bot \right )\mathclose {}}=d_\bullet \bot . For the latter, we must check that k\circ \eta _{A_\infty }=k'\circ \eta _{A_\infty }; by the universal property of the colimiting cocone {A_\bullet }\xrightarrow {{\iota _\bullet }}{A_\infty }, it suffices to check that k\circ \eta _{A_\infty }\circ \iota _\bullet = k'\circ \eta _{A_\infty }\circ \iota _\bullet . By naturality of the unit, these are both equal to d_\bullet \circ \eta _{A_\bullet }.

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let \mathbb {L}={\mathopen {}\left (\mathsf {L},\eta ,\mu \right )\mathclose {}} be the lifting monad on dcpos; the Eilenberg–Moore category \mathsf {dcpo}^{\mathbb {L}} is closed under connected colimits, and these colimits are created by the forgetful functor {\mathsf {dcpo}^{\mathbb {L}}}\xrightarrow {{\mathsf {U}^{\mathbb {L}}}}{\mathsf {dcpo}}.
This follows from the following facts:

html:ol.html:li: The category of dcpos is (even constructively) known to be cocomplete.
Lifting preserves connected colimits.
The forgetful functor {\mathsf {dcpo}^{\mathbb {L}}}\xrightarrow {{\mathsf {U}^{\mathbb {L}}}}{\mathsf {dcpo}} creates whatever colimits \mathsf {L} preserves.

fr:mainmatter.html:p: The Eilenberg–Moore category \mathsf {dcpo}^{\mathbb {L}} for the lifting monad \mathbb {L}={\mathopen {}\left (\mathsf {L},\eta ,\mu \right )\mathclose {}} on dcpos has all small coproducts.
This is the first part of Corollary 2 of Linton's Coequalizers in categories of algebras.

The coproduct of lift-algebras is computed as a reflexive coequalizer, whose existence we have already established. Given an index set I and a diagram {I}\xrightarrow {{X_{\bullet }}}{\mathsf {dcpo}^{\mathbb {L}}}, the colimit of the following reflexive pair is the coproduct of {I}\xrightarrow {{X_{\bullet }}}{\mathsf {dcpo}^{\mathbb {L}}} as shown by Linton:

fr:title.text: The category of lift-algebras is cocomplete

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: The category of lift-algebras is cocomplete

fr:mainmatter.html:p: The Eilenberg–Moore category \mathsf {dcpo}^{\mathbb {L}} for the lifting monad \mathbb {L}={\mathopen {}\left (\mathsf {L},\eta ,\mu \right )\mathclose {}} on dcpos is cocomplete.
This follows because \mathsf {dcpo}^{\mathbb {L}} under connected colimits and coproducts
We will develop the theory of functors between displayed categories or fibrations as well as natural transformations between these functors, building on Ahrens and Lumsdaine and Jacobs.

Let X be a displayed category over B and let Y be a displayed category over C, and let {B}\xrightarrow {{F}}{C} be a functor. A displayed functor from X to Y over F, written {X}\xrightarrow [F]{\bar F}{Y} is defined by the following data:

html:ol.html:li: for each displayed object x\in X^b, an assigned object \bar F_b x \in Y^{F b};
for each displayed morphism {x}\xrightarrow [f]{\bar {f}}{y} in X over {b}\xrightarrow {{f}}{c} in B, an assigned morphism {\bar F_b{x}}\xrightarrow [F{f}]{\bar F_f\bar {f}}{\bar F_c y};
such that \bar F_{1_{b}} 1_{x} = 1_{\bar F_b x} and \bar F_{f;g}{\mathopen {}\left (\bar {f};\bar {g}\right )\mathclose {}}=\bar F_f{\bar {f}};\bar F_g{\bar {g}}.

fr:mainmatter.html:p: When it does not cause confusion, we may drop some of the subscripts in our notation.
The notion of fibered functor below makes sense for arbitrary displayed categories, but it is most useful when applied to fibrations.

Let X be a displayed category over B and let Y be a displayed category over C, and let {B}\xrightarrow {{F}}{C} be a functor. A displayed functor from X to Y over F is called fibered when it preserves cartesian morphisms.

Let X be a displayed category over B and let Y be a displayed category over C, and let {X}\xrightarrow [F]{\bar F}{Y} and {X}\xrightarrow [G]{\bar G}{Y} be two displayed functors over {B}\xrightarrow {{F,G}}{C} respectively. Given a natural transformation {F}\xrightarrow {{\alpha }}{G}, a displayed dinatural transformation from \bar F to \bar G over \alpha , written {\bar F}\xrightarrow [\alpha ]{\bar \alpha }{\bar G}, is defined by the following data:

html:ol.html:li: for each displayed object x\in X^b, an assigned displayed morphism {\bar F{x}}\xrightarrow [\alpha _b]{\bar \alpha _x}{\bar G{x}};
such that for each {x}\xrightarrow [f]{\bar {f}}{y} in X, we have \bar \alpha _x; \bar G\bar {f} = \bar F\bar {f};\bar \alpha _y.

fr:mainmatter.html:p: In practice, we will frequently consider vertical displayed functors between fibrations over the same base category B, i.e. functors displayed over the identity functor {B}\xrightarrow {{1_{B}}}{B}. Likewise, we will often consider vertical natural transformations between vertical functors, i.e. natural transformations whose components are vertical. The vertical and non-vertical perspectives give rise to two different (very large) displayed categories of displayed categories, one with unfixed base, and the other with a fixed base. Both viewpoints are important, but it is important not to get them confused.

We wish to define displayed versions of dinatural transformations, but there is some question of how much verticality to assume in the definition: for instance, we could define a displayed dinatural transformation over a dinatural transformation, or we could define a totally vertical notion of dinatural transformation. It is unclear to me that the latter would be an instance of the former. We will focus on the latter, because it is most useful in practice when using displayed category theory to formalize reasoning over a fixed base category.

Let X and Y be two fibrations over B, and let {X^{\mathsf {op}}\times _{B} X}\xrightarrow [1_{B}]{F,G}{Y} be two vertical fibered functors over B, recalling the theory of opposite fibrations. A vertical dinatural transformation \alpha from F to G is defined by the following data:

html:ol.html:li: for each displayed object x\in X^b, an assigned vertical morphism {F_b{\mathopen {}\left (x,x\right )\mathclose {}}}\xrightarrow [1_{b}]{\alpha _x}{G_b{\mathopen {}\left (x,x\right )\mathclose {}}};

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Above, we have written {x}\xrightarrow [1_{b}]{\gamma _{\bar {f}}}{f^{*}{y}}\in X^b for the vertical gap map factoring {x}\xrightarrow [f]{\bar {f}}{y} through the cartesian map {f^{*}{y}}\xrightarrow [f]{y^{*}f}{x}. We have used the fact that a vertical map in X^{\mathsf {op}} is the same as a vertical map in X going the other way.

fr:title.text: Independent sums in categories of monomorphisms

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Independent sums in categories of monomorphisms

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Independent sums play an important role in the semantics of local state, as developed by Kammar, Levy, Moss, and Staton and further refined by Polzer and Goncharov. Although these authors did not elucidate the universal property of independent sums, they alude to Alex Simpson’s notion of independence structure — which ought to provide, after taking opposite categories, a suitable abstract interface to the notion of independent coproduct. We will explore a special case of this abstract structure that is more concrete than the general case, but nonetheless allows for a conceptual reconstruction of the ideas of Kammar et al. based on simpler and more intuitive universal properties. Although it is important to be able to give explicit computations, a presentation that requires explicit computations does not scale to verifying the beautiful and intricate constructions of op. cit.

A co-span {\mathopen {}\left \{u\hookrightarrow w\hookleftarrow v\right \}\mathclose {}} of monomorphisms in a category \mathcal {C} is called independent when its pullback is a span {\mathopen {}\left \{u \hookleftarrow \mathbf {0}_{\mathcal {C}} \hookrightarrow v\right \}\mathclose {}} in which \mathbf {0}_{\mathcal {C}} is initial in \mathcal {C}.

The independent sum of a pair of objects u,v\in \mathcal {C} defined to be the initial independent co-span {\mathopen {}\left \{u \hookrightarrow u\oplus v \hookleftarrow v\right \}\mathclose {}}, when it exists.

The independent complement of a monomorphism \rho : u\hookrightarrow v in a category \mathcal {C} is, if it exists, the greatest monomorphism v\ominus \rho \hookrightarrow v such that the co-span {\mathopen {}\left \{v\ominus \rho \hookrightarrow v \hookleftarrow u\right \}\mathclose {}} is an independent sum.
Question. Would it suffice to simply ask that the co-span is independent, but not universally so?
In an extensive category, any coproduct co-span {\mathopen {}\left \{u \hookrightarrow u+v \hookleftarrow v\right \}\mathclose {}} is an independent sum.

As soon as the co-span {\mathopen {}\left \{u \hookrightarrow u+v \hookleftarrow v\right \}\mathclose {}} is independent, it evidently satisfies the universal property of independent sums, which is weaker than that of coproducts. Coproduct co-spans are always independent in an extensive category.
In an extensive category \mathcal {C}, the independent complement of a monomorphism is precisely the Heyting complement of that morphism when it exists.
This follows immediately from the fact that independent sums are coproducts in extensive \mathcal {C}.

Given a category \mathcal {C}, we define \mathbf {Inj}{\mathopen {}\left (\mathcal {C}\right )\mathclose {}} to be the wide subcategory of \mathcal {C} spanned by monomorphisms. (As any isomorphism is a monomorphism, the obvious construction of the precategory \mathbf {Inj}{\mathopen {}\left (\mathcal {C}\right )\mathclose {}} gives a category.)
Let \mathcal {C} be an extensive category. Then independent sums are created by the inclusion \mathbf {Inj}{\mathopen {}\left (\mathcal {C}\right )\mathclose {}}\hookrightarrow \mathcal {C}.
Let {B^{\mathsf {op}}\times B}\xrightarrow {{F,G}}{C} be two functors of mixed variance from B to C. A dinatural transformation \alpha from F to G is given by the following data:

html:ol.html:li: for each b\in B, an assigned morphism {F{\mathopen {}\left (b,b\right )\mathclose {}}}\xrightarrow {{\alpha _b}}{G{\mathopen {}\left (b,b\right )\mathclose {}}};

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let X be a displayed category over B and let Y be a displayed category over C, and let {B}\xrightarrow {{F}}{C} be a functor. A displayed functor from X to Y over F is called fibered when it preserves cartesian morphisms.
Let B be a category. A displayed category E over B is defined by the following data according to (Ahrens and Lumsdaine):

html:ol.html:li: for each object x\in B, a collection of displayed objects E_{x},

for each morphism {x}\xrightarrow {{f}}{y}\in B and displayed objects \bar {x}\in E_{x} and \bar {y}\in E_{y}, a family of collections of displayed morphisms \mathbf {hom}_{E_{f}}{\mathopen {}\left (\bar {x},\bar {y}\right )\mathclose {}}, an element of which shall denote by {\bar {x}}\xrightarrow [f]{\bar {f}}{\bar {y}},
for each x\in B and \bar {x}\in E_{x}, a displayed morphism {\bar {x}}\xrightarrow [1_{x}]{1_{\bar {x}}}{\bar {x}},

fr:mainmatter.html:p: When we have too many subscripts, we will write E[x] instead of E_{x}.

A displayed category E over B is said to be a cartesian fibration, when for each morphism {x}\xrightarrow {{f}}{y} and displayed object \bar {y}\in E_{y}, there exists a displayed object \bar {x}\in E_{x} and a cartesian morphism {\bar {x}}\xrightarrow [f]{\bar {f}}{\bar {y}}. Note that the pair (\bar {x},\bar {f}) is unique up to unique isomorphism, so being a cartesian fibration is a property of a displayed category.
We will also refer to cartesian fibrations as simply fibrations or fibered categories.
There are other variations of fibration. For instance, E is said to be an isofibration when the condition above holds just for isomorphisms f : x\cong y in the base.
